message.content:
We need to “close‐out” the inventory account by comparing how much the company purchased (which adds to inventory) versus the cost of what was sold (which removes inventory). In our simplified analysis the opening inventory is nil so that the ending (or “final”) inventory equals:

  Ending Inventory = Total Purchases – Total Cost of Goods Sold

Looking through the table, only rows with type “Purchase” add inventory and rows with type “Sale” carry a “cost_amount” (the cost of the sold goods) that decrease inventory.

Step‐by‐step we get:

1. Sum of all “Purchase” amounts (the “amount” value in Purchase rows):

  • Purchase20231231001: 2,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231002: 1,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231003: 200,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231004: 1,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231005: 20,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231006: 10,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231007: 60,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231008: 60,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231009: 300,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231010: 3,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231011: 200,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231012: 20,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231013: 10,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231014: 15,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231015: 20,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231016: 200,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231017: 1,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231018: 200,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231019: 300,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231020: 40,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231021: 20,000.00  
  • Purchase20231231022: 1,000.00  

Adding these up yields a total purchase cost of 1,684,000.00.

2. Next, sum the “cost_amount” from all “Sale” rows (which tell us how much inventory cost was “used up” during sales):

  • Sale20240103004: 1,000.00  
  • Sale20240104005: 1,000.00  
  • Sale20240105007: 1,000.00  
  • Sale20240106009: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240106010: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240109016: 5,000.00  
  • Sale20240109017: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240109018: 5,000.00  
  • Sale20240110019: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240110020: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240111022: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240113025: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240113026: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240114028: 1,000.00  
  • Sale20240115029: 1,000.00  
  • Sale20240115030: 1,000.00  
  • Sale20240116032: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240116033: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240117035: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240118037: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240118038: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240119040: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240120042: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240122045: 5,000.00  
  • Sale20240122046: 1,000.00  
  • Sale20240122047: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240123048: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240125050: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240125051: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240127055: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240127056: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240127057: 5,000.00  
  • Sale20240129060: 5,000.00  
  • Sale20240130056: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240130057: 60,000.00  
  • Sale20240202063: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240202064: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240203065: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240204068: 5,000.00  
  • Sale20240204069: 20,000.00  
  • Sale20240205070: 5,000.00  
  • Sale20240205071: 100,000.00  
  • Sale20240205072: 1,000.00  

Summing these “cost_amount” values gives a total cost of goods sold equal to 1,848,000.00.

3. Now compute the change in inventory:

  Change in Inventory = Total Purchases – Total Cost of Goods Sold  
     = 1,684,000.00 – 1,848,000.00  
     = –164,000.00

A negative result means there is a net decrease in inventory. In the cash flow statement this “decrease” (or “use”) of inventory will be reported.

Thus the final inventory item (change in inventory) to be reported is –164,000.00.

The answer in the required json format is:

------------------------------------------------

{"solution": {"(Increase) Decrease in Inventory": "-164000.00"}}
